title: Red Solo Cup - Harry one shot
body:
Requested by this anon:

“Can you write something where fratboy harry is dating the weird girl who is friends w a bunch of sorority girls but isn’t in one. And then one day she over hears harry and his friends talking ab how weird she is and she gets offended (obv) and he feels really bad after because she hasn’t talked to him and all of her sorority friends hate him for what he said please and thank you baby goose!!!🤪”

//4k+ words//

Find my masterlist here!

Becks rolled over when she felt Harry playing with her hair.  His eyes were shut and his face looked completely peaceful as his fingers toyed with the ends of her ponytail.  He opened his eyes when he felt her move.

“Morning,” he mumbled, giving her a sleepy smile.

“Good morning,” she whispered, moving a little closer to him.

Harry held one hand on her waist and the other on the back of her neck.  She thought it was funny how different he looked with his duvet pulled up to his chin.  No glimpses of the tattoos covering his body, just his wild, curly hair that he had given up on taming sticking all over his pillowcase.

“Let’s skip class and stay here all day,” he suggested, burying his face in her shoulder.

“No,” Becks rolled her eyes.

“Why?” He whined. “Wanna cuddle.”

“We cuddled all night,” she insisted.

“Not enough,” he mumbled against her skin.

“Well, one of us has to go to class, right?” She asked, ignoring the kisses he pressed to her shoulders.

“No,” he said. “Besides, I do just fine without class.”

“You do just fine because you have pledges doing your homework and taking notes for you,” she reminded him. “I don’t, so I go to class. Besides, I like school.”

Harry looked up at her. “Beck! Come on. You like school more than me?”

“School doesn’t snore,” she retorted.

He quickly got on top of her, sitting on her hips. “School doesn’t do this either, does it?”

“Squish me? It definitely feels like it sometimes,” she said, refusing to play along just yet.

“Not squish you,” he mumbled, bending over and kissing her neck.  

He ran his hands down her bare sides, hearing her breath catch in her chest as his mouth went lower and lower.

“Hmm?” He pressed.

“Mhm, Harry,” she moaned, before sitting up and throwing him off his balance. “Still not skipping.”

“You’re so weird,” he groaned, lying on his back and sadly staring at his growing erection. “Who wants to go to class?”

“Me,” she said, finding her shirt on the floor.

“This is why you should join a sorority. Then you’d have pledges to do your school stuff for you. And you could spend more time with me,” he grinned, watching her get dressed.

“No thanks,” she shook her head. “Have you seen my underwear?”

Harry dangled it from his middle finger. “Got to come over here to get it back.”

Becks tried to grab it, but he held it behind him.  Leaning to get it, he pulled her down on top of him.

“Harry, come on,” she sighed.

“You’re no fun this morning,” he complained.

“Fine,” she sat up. “Guess I’m not wearing underwear today.”

“Really unfair to leave me with that visual!” He yelled after her.

Becks quietly walked down the hallway of the frat house, which was still quiet at this hour.  Niall Horan unexpectedly popped out of his bedroom, trying to button up his shirt and walk at the same time.

“Morning Becks,” he waved.

“Hi,” she smiled.

“Coming to the party tonight?” Niall asked.

“Oh, I forgot about that,” she frowned.

“All the Kappa girls are too,” Niall said. “C’mon, you have to. Harry’ll be all sad and mopey if you don’t.”

Becks blushed. “Yeah, I’ll text Kennedy. What’s the theme?”

“Mathletes and Athletes,” he grinned. “It’s gonna be awesome.”

“I’ll keep that in mind,” she said. “Have a good day.”



Becks really wasn’t envious of her friends outfits as she sat down with them in the dining hall.  There was some event that their sorority was partaking in this afternoon, and that meant wearing letters.  Their nauseating pastel shirts were adorned with Kappa’s Greek letters in neon Lilly Pulitzer prints.

The next time Harry suggested she join the sorority, Becks was going to direct him to one of those shirts.  She would never be caught dead in Lilly Pulitzer, that was for sure.  

It was kind of funny that she’d fallen in with the sorority, given her disdain for Greek life.  It was doubly funny that her boyfriend was the stereotypical frat boy.  But she didn’t make fun of Greek life too much, because without it she wouldn’t have met the girls, or Harry.

Becks had been late for a class freshman year, after missing orientation due to a water skiing accident, and accidentally wandered into the Kappa sorority house while looking for U.S. history.  To this day, she maintained that it wasn’t her fault.  All of the old buildings on campus looked just like the sorority and fraternity houses.

Kennedy had been in the process of telling Becks that she was a stalker who needed to get out when she noticed the shoes Becks had been wearing.

At any other college, Becks would have been the cool girl.  She had an amazing wardrobe, cool connections, and she was beautiful.  But here, at a college where Greek life was more important than anything else, she was a social reject.

When Kennedy noticed her shoes, which had only been made for the Saint Laurent Spring/Summer runway and were impossible to find, they had formed a fast friendship.  What started as a materialistic connection turned into a genuine bond, and with Kennedy’s approval Becks fell in with the Kappa girls.

“Alright, what’s everyone wearing tonight?” Kennedy clapped her hands from the head of the table.

“Something slutty,” was the response she got from most girls.

“And you, my dear Beckett?” Kennedy smiled at Becks.

“Puh-lease do not call me that,” Becks rolled her eyes. “And I don’t know. I’ll just wear a button down with glasses and be a Mathlete.”

The rest of the girls seemed saddened by her inability to see how important outfit choices were at a frat party.

“No, you will wear something tight fitting with glasses,” Kennedy corrected her.

“Why? I have a boyfriend. He’s stuck with me, he knows what I’m working with whether my shirt is tight or not,” Becks groaned. “I don’t even want to go, I’m so tired.”

“Maybe if you would let our pledges take your notes, you could skip class and take a nap,” Priscilla suggested. “As we’ve already told you a million times.”

“I don’t want someone else’s notes,” Becks insisted. “I can take my own.”

If Harry knew that she was completely able to get notes and could skip class more often to hang out with him, he would be rather annoyed.  Not so much because she wasn’t spending time with him, but because she was lying.

He just didn’t get it.  Becks liked school.  She liked sitting in lectures, taking notes, and writing papers.  Not that it was exactly good old fashioned fun, but it was a part of college.  And she didn’t mind one bit.  If she tried to tell her boyfriend, the king of skipping classes, how she felt, he would probably want her tested for illness.

“Everyone will meet tonight in the house living room to pregame at 9,” Kennedy said. “That includes you, Becks.”

“I’m going to go get some homework done before the weekend,” Becks said, standing up. “See you tonight.”



Adjusting her tight, white dress, Becks inspected herself in the mirror.  Little buttons went down the middle of the dress all the way to the bottom, kind of like a button up shirt.  She wore her thick-rimmed black glasses, which were really only for reading the white boards in class.  Her hair was up in a bun, and she was ready to go.

She really wished she could skip the party and go to the end of the night, which would mean getting into bed with Harry.  But the party would be fun.  Probably.

The Kappa girls greeted her warmly when she arrived at the pregame, taking the cup someone handed her.  Sitting down on the couch, she looked at the messages she’d gotten from Harry on her walk here.

She put her phone away, her lack of response sure to drive him insane.  Instead she focused on the girls, who were discussing some fundraiser that involved washing cars in bikinis.  Becks didn’t even wash her own car, she couldn’t imagine washing a stranger’s in one of her swimsuits.

The girls were all giggling and shrieking by the time they arrived at the frat house.  Inside they found an already massive crowd dressed in a mixture of athletic jerseys and sweater vests.  Harry was very easy to spot, standing up on a couch in his basketball jersey and snapback.  Becks winced when Liam Payne threw a beer at his chest, which he caught in the nick of time.

He jumped off the couch when he saw her, pushing through the crowds until he was at her side.  Harry was one of the most popular people on campus, yet he seemed to have no idea.  He’d give polite waves and smiles as he passed, not seeming to realize that all eyes were on him.

“Hi,” he said, giving Becks a kiss. “Hi girls, let me steal her for a bit.”

Kennedy and Priscilla rolled her eyes, knowing full well that they wouldn’t be seeing Becks until tomorrow.

“Missed you,” she smiled at him, wrapping her arms around his neck.

“Not enough to cuddle with me this morning,” he mumbled, tugging on her lower lip. “My pretty girl. Hey, I got us something cool.”

“Is this going to be another vibrator?” She raised an eyebrow.

“Don’t give me that face, you liked it,” he scoffed. “And no, even better. C’mere.”

Becks followed Harry upstairs to his room.  He happily picked up some papers from his printer and handed them to her with a proud smile.

“Plane ticket?” She scanned the sheet in her hands. “You’re going away this Wednesday?”

“Nope,” he shook his head. “We both are.”

“Harry!” Her smile turned into a frown when she saw the dates. “But… I’d be missing four days of class. Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and not getting back in until Monday afternoon.”

“Beck,” Harry said, his shoulders tensing. “I’m taking you on vacation and that’s your first thought? School?”

“No, my first thought is that it’s so sweet of you,” she shook her head. “But that’s a lot of class to miss.”

“Why are you so obsessed with school?” He groaned, flopping back onto his bed.

“Because I’m a student?” She tried.

“Can you just let me do one nice fucking thing?” Harry snapped.

Her mouth opened, because she hadn’t expected him to get so angry so quickly.  Harry’s mom worked for a prominent travel magazine, so she knew he probably got these tickets through her.  And it was so sweet and thoughtful, but she wished he had checked with her before he took them.  She had a test on Thursday, and her lab on Friday.  There was just no way she could miss this much work without her grades severely suffering.

“It’s not like you’re some fucking scholarship kid,” he continued. “You’re not losing anything by not going to class for once in your life. What, are you scared someone will take your seat in the front row?”

“Don’t be mean,” she said, toeing the ground with her sandals.

“Fine, I’m mean, but you’re just ridiculous,” he huffed. “I’m trying to show you how serious I am about you, and about us, and you’re just complaining about stupid shit.”

Becks rolled her eyes at that. “If you want to show me how serious you are, stop swearing at me and having a fit.”

“Fine, I’ll go by myself,” Harry snapped, standing up. “Have fun sitting through lectures that you’ll never need again once you graduate!”

She winced as he slammed his bedroom door behind him, leaving her with the tickets and travel roster.  Gently placing them on his desk, she sucked her lower lip into her mouth.  Why did he have to get so worked up over this?  She could understand that he was disappointed, but he didn’t need to be so mean.

Sighing, she walked downstairs and back into the party.  She knew she should have skipped this.  Refreshing her drink, she decided that maybe she should try and talk to Harry just once more.  If he wasn’t having it, they could talk tomorrow, but she would have preferred to go to sleep with him tonight knowing that they were okay.

Harry was tall, so it was easy to spot him at the beer pong table.  He and Liam were playing against Niall and Louis Tomlinson.  Harry held his hat to his head, as if he were afraid the backwards cap were going to fall off.  Standing in the gathered audience, Becks decided to wait until the game was through to say anything.

But in her sandals she was short, so Harry had no idea his girlfriend was within earshot as he ranted to his friends and the small audience.

“Why’s she like school so much? Like, who gives a fuck?” Harry huffed. “Just miss a few stupid classes to hang out with your boyfriend. She’s such a freak sometimes, and not in the way I like her to be.”

Niall snorted and rolled his eyes, as Becks’ stomach dropped. “None of us are concerned with that aspect. We all hear you two just about every damn night, Harry. Or should I say Daddy?”

Becks’ cheeks burned with humiliation, but she couldn’t bring herself to walk away or speak up.

“As least someone’s calling me something,” Harry rolled his eyes.

“She is really obsessed with school, it’s weird,” Liam agreed. “Why won’t she just join Kappa?”

“Won’t get off her fuckin’ high horse,” Harry muttered, drinking from a cup even though it wasn’t his turn. “She really knows how to get on my nerves. Trying to show her I can be a good boyfriend and this is what I get.”

“Can I come?” Louis asked. “Instead of Becks?”

“Sure, why not? You know what, why don’t you and Eleanor just take the tickets? Like I give a fuck. I might as well be here with the weirdo listening to stories about professors and papers,” Harry sighed dramatically.

Weirdo?  Becks’ jaw clenched.  She could tell from the unfocused look in Harry’s green eyes that he was drunk, but that was no excuse.  They had one little disagreement, and here he was telling anyone within earshot about how strange she was.

“So break up with her,” Liam shrugged.

Harry paused, and the pause broke her heart. “Nah, probably not.”

She had heard enough.  Turning on her heel, she pulled her glasses off and walked through the crowd as tears streaked down her cheeks.  Being a good student wasn’t a crime, at least, it shouldn’t be.  But maybe in the world of Harry Styles where solo cups were textbooks and coming up with lies to get out of things were essays, it was.

“Shit!” She heard Harry yell, and she quickened her pace.

She was not going to cry in front of him, and she wasn’t going to get into an argument in front of the entire party.

“Beck, Becks!” Harry panted, running after her. “Please wait up baby, please.”

“Oh, so now I’m your baby?” She couldn’t help it, turning around and putting her hands on her hips.

“N-no, don’t cry,” he said, reaching forward to dry her tears.

She smacked his hand away. “Don’t touch me.”

Harry sighed heavily. “I didn’t mean any of that, I never would have…”

“What? Never would have said it if you knew I was there? Would have waited until later when I was out of earshot?” She supplied some possible answers for him.

“I…” Harry wasn’t used to being put on the spot.

“I had no idea it was so difficult for you to be around me,” she said quietly, aware that everyone was listening. “Maybe you should stay away to help yourself feel better.”

“No, no,” he shook his head.

“Some boyfriend,” she said under her breath, walking away before he had the chance to come up with something.

She walked and walked, until she found herself back in her own room.  Pulling the dress off, she got into her pajamas as she continued to sob.  But her pajamas were an old t-shirt and boxers of Harry’s, so she ripped those off and got into bed naked.

She and Harry were different, and that was why they worked.  Or so she thought.  He was the crazy frat boy, and she was the good girl.  In some ways they made no sense, yet they meshed together perfectly.

Hearing him complain about her to anyone willing to listen hurt more than she could have imagined.  His words were ringing in her ears, no matter how hard she tried to block them out.  So she stuck her headphones in and fell asleep listening to breakup songs.



“Baby? Please open the door, I know you’re in there,” Harry groaned, leaning his forehead against her door.

Becks sat silently at her little kitchen table, working through a calculus problem.  He’d been out there for approximately thirteen minutes.  They were on day four of not speaking, mostly because of her.  He didn’t call or text her until two days after the incident, and she ignored him.  He kept texting and calling before switching to house calls.  But she hadn’t let him in, she couldn’t.

She felt like their entire two year relationship had been a lie.  They’d had their ups and downs, but nothing had ever been as hurtful as this.  She found herself wondering if maybe Harry was only with her as some sort of extended joke.

“Please?” His voice wobbled, and she held her face in her hands. “I miss you Becks, come on. Can you just talk to me?”

She cried silently, closing her textbook.  Getting work done was impossible when she was so completely miserable.

“Fine,” he mumbled. “I’ll try again tomorrow.”

Becks cried loudly once he was gone.  She didn’t know what to do.  Talking about it was terrifying, but she couldn’t ignore him forever.  He was still her boyfriend, even if he’d fucked up like this.

Kennedy had demanded her presence at dinner in the dining hall, so Becks set to icing her puffy, red eyes and picking out a outfit that had casual yes-I’m-fine undertones.  Sighing, she said a quick prayer that Harry would be eating at the frat house.

When Becks approached the usual Kappa table, she found Niall Horan on his knees at Kennedy’s feet.  Briefly forgetting her own problems, she sat down next to Della.

“Please, you can’t cancel,” Niall moaned. “It’s my favorite day of the year.”

“Oh, sorry Niall,” Kennedy mock pouted. “But Kappa will no longer be fraternizing with you boys. I heard the Alpha Phi girls are free, though. Probably because of that herpes outbreak, but you’ve got to take what you can get.”

“He’s sorry, he’s so sorry,” Niall insisted, grabbing her hands. “You can’t cancel the date party.”

“Too late,” Kennedy said, shaking him off.

“What’s going on?” Becks asked Della.

Della smiled at her. “We decided that we won’t be involved with them anymore. Kennedy told us what Harry was saying, that sucks.”

Becks’ cheeks turned red when she realized she was causing the chasm between the two groups.  On one hand she felt embarrassed, but on the other she hoped Harry was getting all of the blame for this.

“We’ll kick him out of the frat,” Niall said firmly. “Just say the word, he’s gone.”

“Well?” Kennedy raised an eyebrow, looking at Becks.

“No!” Becks shook her head rapidly. “You can’t kick him out, that’s insane. Just have the stupid date party.”

“What she said!” Niall nodded.

“She’s nice,” Kennedy frowned. “I’m not. Maybe you’ll remember this when you’re recruiting next year.”

Niall finally gave up, glaring at the table Harry was at as he left the dining hall. “Hey man, fuck you!”

Becks slouched lower in her seat, hoping that nobody knew what was going on and that it all revolved around her.

“You can have the party,” she said quietly, looking at Kennedy.

“No, we can’t,” Kennedy said firmly. “They’re clearly not up to par if that’s how they talk about people. It wasn’t just Harry, it was his friends. And Niall Horan kind of creeps me out, anyways.”

Priscilla, who frequently hooked up with Niall, rolled her eyes at that.

“So what are you doing if you’re not having the party?” Becks asked. “Don’t you have the place rented out and stuff?”

“She’s right,” Della frowned.

“Oh my God, I know!” Kennedy clapped her hands suddenly. “Makeover party!”

Becks winced, but the other girls all seemed thrilled at the prospect.  Everyone began calling her favorite salon to request their stylists for the night, giggling to one another as they were put on hold.

“And obviously you’re coming,” Kennedy said.

Becks pretended not to hear.

“Beckett, hello?” Kennedy said louder.

“Oh my God, stop,” Becks huffed. “Fine.”

“I hope the bar lets us have a makeover party,” Kennedy frowned. “Oh well, I’m sure it’ll be fine.”

Becks ate some of her salad as the girls planned.  She figured that even if she was losing her boyfriend, she still had some pretty amazing friends.



“Why do you even come to the library?” Priscilla asked. “You get straight A’s even if you don’t study.”

“Just wanted a change of scenery,” Becks mumbled.

She was seated at the Kappa table in the library, which was currently full of sorority sisters cramming for their midterms.  Not that Becks needed to fit any more studying in, but staying in her own room was a hazard.  Harry was constantly trying to talk to her, so she needed some peace and quiet.  Unfortunately, that meant sitting in the library.

“Oh my God,” Della whispered. “Look.”

Becks didn’t bother looking up.  She didn’t want to gossip or people watch.  She just wanted to get a head start on her reading, go to bed, and hopefully not cry tonight.  It had now been six days since she spoke to Harry.  She thought that it would get easier, but it didn’t.  It was still just as heartbreaking as it had been in that moment.

“Look!” Kennedy pinched her thigh, making her jump.

“What?” Becks hissed.

Kennedy nodded at the entrance.  The girls always sat on the third floor of the library, because everyone knew that was the cool area.  It was the best place for people watching, and the Starbucks was on this floor.

Harry was walking in, carrying a bouquet of flowers and wearing a flannel.  In other words, dressed up more so than usual.  Running a hand through his hair, his eyes locked with hers.

“Good evening, ladies,” he said, approaching the table.

“Walk away,” Kennedy said, leaning back in her seat and crossing her arms over her chest.

“Don’t think so,” he said, giving her an annoying little smile as he stepped up onto the table. “Uh, excuse me? Can I have everyone’s attention?”

Had anyone else stepped on a table in the middle of the library and demanded everyone’s consideration, they would have been laughed out of the building.  But it was Harry, so people stopped what they were doing and listened.

“So last week, I really hurt my girlfriend’s feelings at a party. I was trying to do something nice, but I didn’t really ask her about her opinion on the matter and I got really frustrated and screamed at her,” Harry sighed, not even blushing under all of the eyes on him.

Becks stared up at him with wide eyes, unable to believe this was happening.

“And after that I got really drunk, and I was telling anyone who would listen all sorts of lies to make myself feel better about fucking up. I thought she’d left, but she was there and she heard. Hi, Beck, how’s it going?” He smiled down at her, seeming to forget where he was for a moment.

“Hi,” she whispered, hands shaking as she held her book.

“Now you won’t talk to me. You ignore me when I knock at your door, and all of your friends are ignoring me too. And I… I can’t lose you. I don’t want to go back to life without you,” he shook his head.

Several girls let out awww’s at that.

“I love you more than anything. I love you as much as you love school. Which is fine, there’s nothing wrong with loving school. Someone’s got to, I suppose,” he said, giving her a tiny smile. “And I shouldn’t make fun of you, or anyone else, to make myself feel better. I should never have jeopardized our relationship. I know that now.”

Her eyes were tearing now, because it was like he’d somehow read her mind and figured out everything she wanted to hear in an apology.

“Please just talk to me,” he begged, getting down on his knees so he was nearly at her level. “I miss you so much, and I love you.”

“Harry,” she sniffled, wiping a tear away.

“Hmm?” He leaned in closer, an anxious look on his face.

“I love you too, can you get down?” She asked, smiling at him.

Harry sat down on her notebooks.  He handed her the bouquet he’d been holding, smiling shyly.

“I miss you so much,” he mumbled, finally noticing how everyone was watching with rapt attention.

“I miss you too,” she nodded, hugging the flowers to her chest.

Becks stood up and kissed him, making everyone begin to applaud wildly.  Her cheeks burned as she buried her face against his neck.  Harry placed his hands on the small of her back, pressing kisses to the top of her head.

“I am so sorry,” he sighed. “More than I can say. I love you and your books and flashcards and all of it.”

“I love you too,” she murmured, picking her head up as the clapping subsided.

“You wanna sleep over tonight?” He asked, pulling her closer.

“Let’s sleep at mine,” she suggested, indicating the flowers. “I should put these in water.”

“Right,” he agreed, picking up her things and shouldering her backpack. “Oh, and Kennedy?”

“Yeah?” Kennedy tried to stop smiling at the cuteness.

“Please still have the formal, I think Niall’s experiencing clinical depression over it,” he grinned.

“I’ll see what I can do,” she nodded.

“You and I aren’t going,” Harry told Becks as they walked out of the library.

“Why?” She frowned.

“Because we won’t be here that weekend,” he shook his head. “Our flight leaves after your Friday lab, and we get back Sunday around eleven at night. Don’t worry about being tired for your Monday morning lit class, I talked to your professor and she was going to cancel that class anyways.”

“Really?” She smiled widely.

“You shouldn’t miss stuff if you don’t want to,” he shrugged, holding her hand tightly. “And I checked with all of your other professors, you haven’t got any tests or papers due the week we’re back, so you shouldn’t have too much homework.”

She stopped and kissed him. “I love you.”

“I love you like Niall loves Kappa,” he grinned.

“Shut up,” she rolled her eyes.

“In all seriousness,” Harry cleared his throat. “I fucked up and I want to make it up to you. Whatever it takes.”

“You don’t have to make it up to me,” she shook her head, unlocking her door.

“I can try,” he grinned, putting the flowers down. “Now c’mere, it’s been a lonely six days.”

a/n: would like to take this time to say that i’m v v v saddened by the fact that none of my readers likened the title of my last harry one shot (holiday in the sun) to mary kate and ashley’s second most iconic film

ok hope you enjoyed

“Morning,” he mumbled, giving her a sleepy smile.

“Good morning,” she whispered, moving a little closer to him.

Harry held one hand on her waist and the other on the back of her neck.  She thought it was funny how different he looked with his duvet pulled up to his chin.  No glimpses of the tattoos covering his body, just his wild, curly hair that he had given up on taming sticking all over his pillowcase.

“Let’s skip class and stay here all day,” he suggested, burying his face in her shoulder.

“No,” Becks rolled her eyes.

“Why?” He whined. “Wanna cuddle.”

“We cuddled all night,” she insisted.

“Not enough,” he mumbled against her skin.

“Well, one of us has to go to class, right?” She asked, ignoring the kisses he pressed to her shoulders.

“No,” he said. “Besides, I do just fine without class.”

“You do just fine because you have pledges doing your homework and taking notes for you,” she reminded him. “I don’t, so I go to class. Besides, I like school.”

Harry looked up at her. “Beck! Come on. You like school more than me?”

“School doesn’t snore,” she retorted.

He quickly got on top of her, sitting on her hips. “School doesn’t do this either, does it?”

“Squish me? It definitely feels like it sometimes,” she said, refusing to play along just yet.

“Not squish you,” he mumbled, bending over and kissing her neck.  

He ran his hands down her bare sides, hearing her breath catch in her chest as his mouth went lower and lower.

“Hmm?” He pressed.

“Mhm, Harry,” she moaned, before sitting up and throwing him off his balance. “Still not skipping.”

“You’re so weird,” he groaned, lying on his back and sadly staring at his growing erection. “Who wants to go to class?”

“Me,” she said, finding her shirt on the floor.

“This is why you should join a sorority. Then you’d have pledges to do your school stuff for you. And you could spend more time with me,” he grinned, watching her get dressed.

“No thanks,” she shook her head. “Have you seen my underwear?”

Harry dangled it from his middle finger. “Got to come over here to get it back.”

Becks tried to grab it, but he held it behind him.  Leaning to get it, he pulled her down on top of him.

“Harry, come on,” she sighed.

“You’re no fun this morning,” he complained.

“Fine,” she sat up. “Guess I’m not wearing underwear today.”

“Really unfair to leave me with that visual!” He yelled after her.

Becks quietly walked down the hallway of the frat house, which was still quiet at this hour.  Niall Horan unexpectedly popped out of his bedroom, trying to button up his shirt and walk at the same time.

“Morning Becks,” he waved.

“Hi,” she smiled.

“Coming to the party tonight?” Niall asked.

“Oh, I forgot about that,” she frowned.

“All the Kappa girls are too,” Niall said. “C’mon, you have to. Harry’ll be all sad and mopey if you don’t.”

Becks blushed. “Yeah, I’ll text Kennedy. What’s the theme?”

“Mathletes and Athletes,” he grinned. “It’s gonna be awesome.”

“I’ll keep that in mind,” she said. “Have a good day.”



Becks really wasn’t envious of her friends outfits as she sat down with them in the dining hall.  There was some event that their sorority was partaking in this afternoon, and that meant wearing letters.  Their nauseating pastel shirts were adorned with Kappa’s Greek letters in neon Lilly Pulitzer prints.

The next time Harry suggested she join the sorority, Becks was going to direct him to one of those shirts.  She would never be caught dead in Lilly Pulitzer, that was for sure.  

It was kind of funny that she’d fallen in with the sorority, given her disdain for Greek life.  It was doubly funny that her boyfriend was the stereotypical frat boy.  But she didn’t make fun of Greek life too much, because without it she wouldn’t have met the girls, or Harry.

Becks had been late for a class freshman year, after missing orientation due to a water skiing accident, and accidentally wandered into the Kappa sorority house while looking for U.S. history.  To this day, she maintained that it wasn’t her fault.  All of the old buildings on campus looked just like the sorority and fraternity houses.

Kennedy had been in the process of telling Becks that she was a stalker who needed to get out when she noticed the shoes Becks had been wearing.

At any other college, Becks would have been the cool girl.  She had an amazing wardrobe, cool connections, and she was beautiful.  But here, at a college where Greek life was more important than anything else, she was a social reject.

When Kennedy noticed her shoes, which had only been made for the Saint Laurent Spring/Summer runway and were impossible to find, they had formed a fast friendship.  What started as a materialistic connection turned into a genuine bond, and with Kennedy’s approval Becks fell in with the Kappa girls.

“Alright, what’s everyone wearing tonight?” Kennedy clapped her hands from the head of the table.

“Something slutty,” was the response she got from most girls.

“And you, my dear Beckett?” Kennedy smiled at Becks.

“Puh-lease do not call me that,” Becks rolled her eyes. “And I don’t know. I’ll just wear a button down with glasses and be a Mathlete.”

The rest of the girls seemed saddened by her inability to see how important outfit choices were at a frat party.

“No, you will wear something tight fitting with glasses,” Kennedy corrected her.

“Why? I have a boyfriend. He’s stuck with me, he knows what I’m working with whether my shirt is tight or not,” Becks groaned. “I don’t even want to go, I’m so tired.”

“Maybe if you would let our pledges take your notes, you could skip class and take a nap,” Priscilla suggested. “As we’ve already told you a million times.”

“I don’t want someone else’s notes,” Becks insisted. “I can take my own.”

If Harry knew that she was completely able to get notes and could skip class more often to hang out with him, he would be rather annoyed.  Not so much because she wasn’t spending time with him, but because she was lying.

He just didn’t get it.  Becks liked school.  She liked sitting in lectures, taking notes, and writing papers.  Not that it was exactly good old fashioned fun, but it was a part of college.  And she didn’t mind one bit.  If she tried to tell her boyfriend, the king of skipping classes, how she felt, he would probably want her tested for illness.

“Everyone will meet tonight in the house living room to pregame at 9,” Kennedy said. “That includes you, Becks.”

“I’m going to go get some homework done before the weekend,” Becks said, standing up. “See you tonight.”



Adjusting her tight, white dress, Becks inspected herself in the mirror.  Little buttons went down the middle of the dress all the way to the bottom, kind of like a button up shirt.  She wore her thick-rimmed black glasses, which were really only for reading the white boards in class.  Her hair was up in a bun, and she was ready to go.

She really wished she could skip the party and go to the end of the night, which would mean getting into bed with Harry.  But the party would be fun.  Probably.

The Kappa girls greeted her warmly when she arrived at the pregame, taking the cup someone handed her.  Sitting down on the couch, she looked at the messages she’d gotten from Harry on her walk here.

She put her phone away, her lack of response sure to drive him insane.  Instead she focused on the girls, who were discussing some fundraiser that involved washing cars in bikinis.  Becks didn’t even wash her own car, she couldn’t imagine washing a stranger’s in one of her swimsuits.

The girls were all giggling and shrieking by the time they arrived at the frat house.  Inside they found an already massive crowd dressed in a mixture of athletic jerseys and sweater vests.  Harry was very easy to spot, standing up on a couch in his basketball jersey and snapback.  Becks winced when Liam Payne threw a beer at his chest, which he caught in the nick of time.

He jumped off the couch when he saw her, pushing through the crowds until he was at her side.  Harry was one of the most popular people on campus, yet he seemed to have no idea.  He’d give polite waves and smiles as he passed, not seeming to realize that all eyes were on him.

“Hi,” he said, giving Becks a kiss. “Hi girls, let me steal her for a bit.”

Kennedy and Priscilla rolled her eyes, knowing full well that they wouldn’t be seeing Becks until tomorrow.

“Missed you,” she smiled at him, wrapping her arms around his neck.

“Not enough to cuddle with me this morning,” he mumbled, tugging on her lower lip. “My pretty girl. Hey, I got us something cool.”

“Is this going to be another vibrator?” She raised an eyebrow.

“Don’t give me that face, you liked it,” he scoffed. “And no, even better. C’mere.”

Becks followed Harry upstairs to his room.  He happily picked up some papers from his printer and handed them to her with a proud smile.

“Plane ticket?” She scanned the sheet in her hands. “You’re going away this Wednesday?”

“Nope,” he shook his head. “We both are.”

“Harry!” Her smile turned into a frown when she saw the dates. “But… I’d be missing four days of class. Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and not getting back in until Monday afternoon.”

“Beck,” Harry said, his shoulders tensing. “I’m taking you on vacation and that’s your first thought? School?”

“No, my first thought is that it’s so sweet of you,” she shook her head. “But that’s a lot of class to miss.”

“Why are you so obsessed with school?” He groaned, flopping back onto his bed.

“Because I’m a student?” She tried.

“Can you just let me do one nice fucking thing?” Harry snapped.

Her mouth opened, because she hadn’t expected him to get so angry so quickly.  Harry’s mom worked for a prominent travel magazine, so she knew he probably got these tickets through her.  And it was so sweet and thoughtful, but she wished he had checked with her before he took them.  She had a test on Thursday, and her lab on Friday.  There was just no way she could miss this much work without her grades severely suffering.

“It’s not like you’re some fucking scholarship kid,” he continued. “You’re not losing anything by not going to class for once in your life. What, are you scared someone will take your seat in the front row?”

“Don’t be mean,” she said, toeing the ground with her sandals.

“Fine, I’m mean, but you’re just ridiculous,” he huffed. “I’m trying to show you how serious I am about you, and about us, and you’re just complaining about stupid shit.”

Becks rolled her eyes at that. “If you want to show me how serious you are, stop swearing at me and having a fit.”

“Fine, I’ll go by myself,” Harry snapped, standing up. “Have fun sitting through lectures that you’ll never need again once you graduate!”

She winced as he slammed his bedroom door behind him, leaving her with the tickets and travel roster.  Gently placing them on his desk, she sucked her lower lip into her mouth.  Why did he have to get so worked up over this?  She could understand that he was disappointed, but he didn’t need to be so mean.

Sighing, she walked downstairs and back into the party.  She knew she should have skipped this.  Refreshing her drink, she decided that maybe she should try and talk to Harry just once more.  If he wasn’t having it, they could talk tomorrow, but she would have preferred to go to sleep with him tonight knowing that they were okay.

Harry was tall, so it was easy to spot him at the beer pong table.  He and Liam were playing against Niall and Louis Tomlinson.  Harry held his hat to his head, as if he were afraid the backwards cap were going to fall off.  Standing in the gathered audience, Becks decided to wait until the game was through to say anything.

But in her sandals she was short, so Harry had no idea his girlfriend was within earshot as he ranted to his friends and the small audience.

“Why’s she like school so much? Like, who gives a fuck?” Harry huffed. “Just miss a few stupid classes to hang out with your boyfriend. She’s such a freak sometimes, and not in the way I like her to be.”

Niall snorted and rolled his eyes, as Becks’ stomach dropped. “None of us are concerned with that aspect. We all hear you two just about every damn night, Harry. Or should I say Daddy?”

Becks’ cheeks burned with humiliation, but she couldn’t bring herself to walk away or speak up.

“As least someone’s calling me something,” Harry rolled his eyes.

“She is really obsessed with school, it’s weird,” Liam agreed. “Why won’t she just join Kappa?”

“Won’t get off her fuckin’ high horse,” Harry muttered, drinking from a cup even though it wasn’t his turn. “She really knows how to get on my nerves. Trying to show her I can be a good boyfriend and this is what I get.”

“Can I come?” Louis asked. “Instead of Becks?”

“Sure, why not? You know what, why don’t you and Eleanor just take the tickets? Like I give a fuck. I might as well be here with the weirdo listening to stories about professors and papers,” Harry sighed dramatically.

Weirdo?  Becks’ jaw clenched.  She could tell from the unfocused look in Harry’s green eyes that he was drunk, but that was no excuse.  They had one little disagreement, and here he was telling anyone within earshot about how strange she was.

“So break up with her,” Liam shrugged.

Harry paused, and the pause broke her heart. “Nah, probably not.”

She had heard enough.  Turning on her heel, she pulled her glasses off and walked through the crowd as tears streaked down her cheeks.  Being a good student wasn’t a crime, at least, it shouldn’t be.  But maybe in the world of Harry Styles where solo cups were textbooks and coming up with lies to get out of things were essays, it was.

“Shit!” She heard Harry yell, and she quickened her pace.

She was not going to cry in front of him, and she wasn’t going to get into an argument in front of the entire party.

“Beck, Becks!” Harry panted, running after her. “Please wait up baby, please.”

“Oh, so now I’m your baby?” She couldn’t help it, turning around and putting her hands on her hips.

“N-no, don’t cry,” he said, reaching forward to dry her tears.

She smacked his hand away. “Don’t touch me.”

Harry sighed heavily. “I didn’t mean any of that, I never would have…”

“What? Never would have said it if you knew I was there? Would have waited until later when I was out of earshot?” She supplied some possible answers for him.

“I…” Harry wasn’t used to being put on the spot.

“I had no idea it was so difficult for you to be around me,” she said quietly, aware that everyone was listening. “Maybe you should stay away to help yourself feel better.”

“No, no,” he shook his head.

“Some boyfriend,” she said under her breath, walking away before he had the chance to come up with something.

She walked and walked, until she found herself back in her own room.  Pulling the dress off, she got into her pajamas as she continued to sob.  But her pajamas were an old t-shirt and boxers of Harry’s, so she ripped those off and got into bed naked.

She and Harry were different, and that was why they worked.  Or so she thought.  He was the crazy frat boy, and she was the good girl.  In some ways they made no sense, yet they meshed together perfectly.

Hearing him complain about her to anyone willing to listen hurt more than she could have imagined.  His words were ringing in her ears, no matter how hard she tried to block them out.  So she stuck her headphones in and fell asleep listening to breakup songs.



“Baby? Please open the door, I know you’re in there,” Harry groaned, leaning his forehead against her door.

Becks sat silently at her little kitchen table, working through a calculus problem.  He’d been out there for approximately thirteen minutes.  They were on day four of not speaking, mostly because of her.  He didn’t call or text her until two days after the incident, and she ignored him.  He kept texting and calling before switching to house calls.  But she hadn’t let him in, she couldn’t.

She felt like their entire two year relationship had been a lie.  They’d had their ups and downs, but nothing had ever been as hurtful as this.  She found herself wondering if maybe Harry was only with her as some sort of extended joke.

“Please?” His voice wobbled, and she held her face in her hands. “I miss you Becks, come on. Can you just talk to me?”

She cried silently, closing her textbook.  Getting work done was impossible when she was so completely miserable.

“Fine,” he mumbled. “I’ll try again tomorrow.”

Becks cried loudly once he was gone.  She didn’t know what to do.  Talking about it was terrifying, but she couldn’t ignore him forever.  He was still her boyfriend, even if he’d fucked up like this.

Kennedy had demanded her presence at dinner in the dining hall, so Becks set to icing her puffy, red eyes and picking out a outfit that had casual yes-I’m-fine undertones.  Sighing, she said a quick prayer that Harry would be eating at the frat house.

When Becks approached the usual Kappa table, she found Niall Horan on his knees at Kennedy’s feet.  Briefly forgetting her own problems, she sat down next to Della.

“Please, you can’t cancel,” Niall moaned. “It’s my favorite day of the year.”

“Oh, sorry Niall,” Kennedy mock pouted. “But Kappa will no longer be fraternizing with you boys. I heard the Alpha Phi girls are free, though. Probably because of that herpes outbreak, but you’ve got to take what you can get.”

“He’s sorry, he’s so sorry,” Niall insisted, grabbing her hands. “You can’t cancel the date party.”

“Too late,” Kennedy said, shaking him off.

“What’s going on?” Becks asked Della.

Della smiled at her. “We decided that we won’t be involved with them anymore. Kennedy told us what Harry was saying, that sucks.”

Becks’ cheeks turned red when she realized she was causing the chasm between the two groups.  On one hand she felt embarrassed, but on the other she hoped Harry was getting all of the blame for this.

“We’ll kick him out of the frat,” Niall said firmly. “Just say the word, he’s gone.”

“Well?” Kennedy raised an eyebrow, looking at Becks.

“No!” Becks shook her head rapidly. “You can’t kick him out, that’s insane. Just have the stupid date party.”

“What she said!” Niall nodded.

“She’s nice,” Kennedy frowned. “I’m not. Maybe you’ll remember this when you’re recruiting next year.”

Niall finally gave up, glaring at the table Harry was at as he left the dining hall. “Hey man, fuck you!”

Becks slouched lower in her seat, hoping that nobody knew what was going on and that it all revolved around her.

“You can have the party,” she said quietly, looking at Kennedy.

“No, we can’t,” Kennedy said firmly. “They’re clearly not up to par if that’s how they talk about people. It wasn’t just Harry, it was his friends. And Niall Horan kind of creeps me out, anyways.”

Priscilla, who frequently hooked up with Niall, rolled her eyes at that.

“So what are you doing if you’re not having the party?” Becks asked. “Don’t you have the place rented out and stuff?”

“She’s right,” Della frowned.

“Oh my God, I know!” Kennedy clapped her hands suddenly. “Makeover party!”

Becks winced, but the other girls all seemed thrilled at the prospect.  Everyone began calling her favorite salon to request their stylists for the night, giggling to one another as they were put on hold.

“And obviously you’re coming,” Kennedy said.

Becks pretended not to hear.

“Beckett, hello?” Kennedy said louder.

“Oh my God, stop,” Becks huffed. “Fine.”

“I hope the bar lets us have a makeover party,” Kennedy frowned. “Oh well, I’m sure it’ll be fine.”

Becks ate some of her salad as the girls planned.  She figured that even if she was losing her boyfriend, she still had some pretty amazing friends.



“Why do you even come to the library?” Priscilla asked. “You get straight A’s even if you don’t study.”

“Just wanted a change of scenery,” Becks mumbled.

She was seated at the Kappa table in the library, which was currently full of sorority sisters cramming for their midterms.  Not that Becks needed to fit any more studying in, but staying in her own room was a hazard.  Harry was constantly trying to talk to her, so she needed some peace and quiet.  Unfortunately, that meant sitting in the library.

“Oh my God,” Della whispered. “Look.”

Becks didn’t bother looking up.  She didn’t want to gossip or people watch.  She just wanted to get a head start on her reading, go to bed, and hopefully not cry tonight.  It had now been six days since she spoke to Harry.  She thought that it would get easier, but it didn’t.  It was still just as heartbreaking as it had been in that moment.

“Look!” Kennedy pinched her thigh, making her jump.

“What?” Becks hissed.

Kennedy nodded at the entrance.  The girls always sat on the third floor of the library, because everyone knew that was the cool area.  It was the best place for people watching, and the Starbucks was on this floor.

Harry was walking in, carrying a bouquet of flowers and wearing a flannel.  In other words, dressed up more so than usual.  Running a hand through his hair, his eyes locked with hers.

“Good evening, ladies,” he said, approaching the table.

“Walk away,” Kennedy said, leaning back in her seat and crossing her arms over her chest.

“Don’t think so,” he said, giving her an annoying little smile as he stepped up onto the table. “Uh, excuse me? Can I have everyone’s attention?”

Had anyone else stepped on a table in the middle of the library and demanded everyone’s consideration, they would have been laughed out of the building.  But it was Harry, so people stopped what they were doing and listened.

“So last week, I really hurt my girlfriend’s feelings at a party. I was trying to do something nice, but I didn’t really ask her about her opinion on the matter and I got really frustrated and screamed at her,” Harry sighed, not even blushing under all of the eyes on him.

Becks stared up at him with wide eyes, unable to believe this was happening.

“And after that I got really drunk, and I was telling anyone who would listen all sorts of lies to make myself feel better about fucking up. I thought she’d left, but she was there and she heard. Hi, Beck, how’s it going?” He smiled down at her, seeming to forget where he was for a moment.

“Hi,” she whispered, hands shaking as she held her book.

“Now you won’t talk to me. You ignore me when I knock at your door, and all of your friends are ignoring me too. And I… I can’t lose you. I don’t want to go back to life without you,” he shook his head.

Several girls let out awww’s at that.

“I love you more than anything. I love you as much as you love school. Which is fine, there’s nothing wrong with loving school. Someone’s got to, I suppose,” he said, giving her a tiny smile. “And I shouldn’t make fun of you, or anyone else, to make myself feel better. I should never have jeopardized our relationship. I know that now.”

Her eyes were tearing now, because it was like he’d somehow read her mind and figured out everything she wanted to hear in an apology.

“Please just talk to me,” he begged, getting down on his knees so he was nearly at her level. “I miss you so much, and I love you.”

“Harry,” she sniffled, wiping a tear away.

“Hmm?” He leaned in closer, an anxious look on his face.

“I love you too, can you get down?” She asked, smiling at him.

Harry sat down on her notebooks.  He handed her the bouquet he’d been holding, smiling shyly.

“I miss you so much,” he mumbled, finally noticing how everyone was watching with rapt attention.

“I miss you too,” she nodded, hugging the flowers to her chest.

Becks stood up and kissed him, making everyone begin to applaud wildly.  Her cheeks burned as she buried her face against his neck.  Harry placed his hands on the small of her back, pressing kisses to the top of her head.

“I am so sorry,” he sighed. “More than I can say. I love you and your books and flashcards and all of it.”

“I love you too,” she murmured, picking her head up as the clapping subsided.

“You wanna sleep over tonight?” He asked, pulling her closer.

“Let’s sleep at mine,” she suggested, indicating the flowers. “I should put these in water.”

“Right,” he agreed, picking up her things and shouldering her backpack. “Oh, and Kennedy?”

“Yeah?” Kennedy tried to stop smiling at the cuteness.

“Please still have the formal, I think Niall’s experiencing clinical depression over it,” he grinned.

“I’ll see what I can do,” she nodded.

“You and I aren’t going,” Harry told Becks as they walked out of the library.

“Why?” She frowned.

“Because we won’t be here that weekend,” he shook his head. “Our flight leaves after your Friday lab, and we get back Sunday around eleven at night. Don’t worry about being tired for your Monday morning lit class, I talked to your professor and she was going to cancel that class anyways.”

“Really?” She smiled widely.

“You shouldn’t miss stuff if you don’t want to,” he shrugged, holding her hand tightly. “And I checked with all of your other professors, you haven’t got any tests or papers due the week we’re back, so you shouldn’t have too much homework.”

She stopped and kissed him. “I love you.”

“I love you like Niall loves Kappa,” he grinned.

“Shut up,” she rolled her eyes.

“In all seriousness,” Harry cleared his throat. “I fucked up and I want to make it up to you. Whatever it takes.”

“You don’t have to make it up to me,” she shook her head, unlocking her door.

“I can try,” he grinned, putting the flowers down. “Now c’mere, it’s been a lonely six days.”

The next time Harry suggested she join the sorority, Becks was going to direct him to one of those shirts.  She would never be caught dead in Lilly Pulitzer, that was for sure.  

It was kind of funny that she’d fallen in with the sorority, given her disdain for Greek life.  It was doubly funny that her boyfriend was the stereotypical frat boy.  But she didn’t make fun of Greek life too much, because without it she wouldn’t have met the girls, or Harry.

Becks had been late for a class freshman year, after missing orientation due to a water skiing accident, and accidentally wandered into the Kappa sorority house while looking for U.S. history.  To this day, she maintained that it wasn’t her fault.  All of the old buildings on campus looked just like the sorority and fraternity houses.

Kennedy had been in the process of telling Becks that she was a stalker who needed to get out when she noticed the shoes Becks had been wearing.

At any other college, Becks would have been the cool girl.  She had an amazing wardrobe, cool connections, and she was beautiful.  But here, at a college where Greek life was more important than anything else, she was a social reject.

When Kennedy noticed her shoes, which had only been made for the Saint Laurent Spring/Summer runway and were impossible to find, they had formed a fast friendship.  What started as a materialistic connection turned into a genuine bond, and with Kennedy’s approval Becks fell in with the Kappa girls.

“Alright, what’s everyone wearing tonight?” Kennedy clapped her hands from the head of the table.

“Something slutty,” was the response she got from most girls.

“And you, my dear Beckett?” Kennedy smiled at Becks.

“Puh-lease do not call me that,” Becks rolled her eyes. “And I don’t know. I’ll just wear a button down with glasses and be a Mathlete.”

The rest of the girls seemed saddened by her inability to see how important outfit choices were at a frat party.

“No, you will wear something tight fitting with glasses,” Kennedy corrected her.

“Why? I have a boyfriend. He’s stuck with me, he knows what I’m working with whether my shirt is tight or not,” Becks groaned. “I don’t even want to go, I’m so tired.”

“Maybe if you would let our pledges take your notes, you could skip class and take a nap,” Priscilla suggested. “As we’ve already told you a million times.”

“I don’t want someone else’s notes,” Becks insisted. “I can take my own.”

If Harry knew that she was completely able to get notes and could skip class more often to hang out with him, he would be rather annoyed.  Not so much because she wasn’t spending time with him, but because she was lying.

He just didn’t get it.  Becks liked school.  She liked sitting in lectures, taking notes, and writing papers.  Not that it was exactly good old fashioned fun, but it was a part of college.  And she didn’t mind one bit.  If she tried to tell her boyfriend, the king of skipping classes, how she felt, he would probably want her tested for illness.

“Everyone will meet tonight in the house living room to pregame at 9,” Kennedy said. “That includes you, Becks.”

“I’m going to go get some homework done before the weekend,” Becks said, standing up. “See you tonight.”



Adjusting her tight, white dress, Becks inspected herself in the mirror.  Little buttons went down the middle of the dress all the way to the bottom, kind of like a button up shirt.  She wore her thick-rimmed black glasses, which were really only for reading the white boards in class.  Her hair was up in a bun, and she was ready to go.

She really wished she could skip the party and go to the end of the night, which would mean getting into bed with Harry.  But the party would be fun.  Probably.

The Kappa girls greeted her warmly when she arrived at the pregame, taking the cup someone handed her.  Sitting down on the couch, she looked at the messages she’d gotten from Harry on her walk here.

She put her phone away, her lack of response sure to drive him insane.  Instead she focused on the girls, who were discussing some fundraiser that involved washing cars in bikinis.  Becks didn’t even wash her own car, she couldn’t imagine washing a stranger’s in one of her swimsuits.

The girls were all giggling and shrieking by the time they arrived at the frat house.  Inside they found an already massive crowd dressed in a mixture of athletic jerseys and sweater vests.  Harry was very easy to spot, standing up on a couch in his basketball jersey and snapback.  Becks winced when Liam Payne threw a beer at his chest, which he caught in the nick of time.

He jumped off the couch when he saw her, pushing through the crowds until he was at her side.  Harry was one of the most popular people on campus, yet he seemed to have no idea.  He’d give polite waves and smiles as he passed, not seeming to realize that all eyes were on him.

“Hi,” he said, giving Becks a kiss. “Hi girls, let me steal her for a bit.”

Kennedy and Priscilla rolled her eyes, knowing full well that they wouldn’t be seeing Becks until tomorrow.

“Missed you,” she smiled at him, wrapping her arms around his neck.

“Not enough to cuddle with me this morning,” he mumbled, tugging on her lower lip. “My pretty girl. Hey, I got us something cool.”

“Is this going to be another vibrator?” She raised an eyebrow.

“Don’t give me that face, you liked it,” he scoffed. “And no, even better. C’mere.”

Becks followed Harry upstairs to his room.  He happily picked up some papers from his printer and handed them to her with a proud smile.

“Plane ticket?” She scanned the sheet in her hands. “You’re going away this Wednesday?”

“Nope,” he shook his head. “We both are.”

“Harry!” Her smile turned into a frown when she saw the dates. “But… I’d be missing four days of class. Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and not getting back in until Monday afternoon.”

“Beck,” Harry said, his shoulders tensing. “I’m taking you on vacation and that’s your first thought? School?”

“No, my first thought is that it’s so sweet of you,” she shook her head. “But that’s a lot of class to miss.”

“Why are you so obsessed with school?” He groaned, flopping back onto his bed.

“Because I’m a student?” She tried.

“Can you just let me do one nice fucking thing?” Harry snapped.

Her mouth opened, because she hadn’t expected him to get so angry so quickly.  Harry’s mom worked for a prominent travel magazine, so she knew he probably got these tickets through her.  And it was so sweet and thoughtful, but she wished he had checked with her before he took them.  She had a test on Thursday, and her lab on Friday.  There was just no way she could miss this much work without her grades severely suffering.

“It’s not like you’re some fucking scholarship kid,” he continued. “You’re not losing anything by not going to class for once in your life. What, are you scared someone will take your seat in the front row?”

“Don’t be mean,” she said, toeing the ground with her sandals.

“Fine, I’m mean, but you’re just ridiculous,” he huffed. “I’m trying to show you how serious I am about you, and about us, and you’re just complaining about stupid shit.”

Becks rolled her eyes at that. “If you want to show me how serious you are, stop swearing at me and having a fit.”

“Fine, I’ll go by myself,” Harry snapped, standing up. “Have fun sitting through lectures that you’ll never need again once you graduate!”

She winced as he slammed his bedroom door behind him, leaving her with the tickets and travel roster.  Gently placing them on his desk, she sucked her lower lip into her mouth.  Why did he have to get so worked up over this?  She could understand that he was disappointed, but he didn’t need to be so mean.

Sighing, she walked downstairs and back into the party.  She knew she should have skipped this.  Refreshing her drink, she decided that maybe she should try and talk to Harry just once more.  If he wasn’t having it, they could talk tomorrow, but she would have preferred to go to sleep with him tonight knowing that they were okay.

Harry was tall, so it was easy to spot him at the beer pong table.  He and Liam were playing against Niall and Louis Tomlinson.  Harry held his hat to his head, as if he were afraid the backwards cap were going to fall off.  Standing in the gathered audience, Becks decided to wait until the game was through to say anything.

But in her sandals she was short, so Harry had no idea his girlfriend was within earshot as he ranted to his friends and the small audience.

“Why’s she like school so much? Like, who gives a fuck?” Harry huffed. “Just miss a few stupid classes to hang out with your boyfriend. She’s such a freak sometimes, and not in the way I like her to be.”

Niall snorted and rolled his eyes, as Becks’ stomach dropped. “None of us are concerned with that aspect. We all hear you two just about every damn night, Harry. Or should I say Daddy?”

Becks’ cheeks burned with humiliation, but she couldn’t bring herself to walk away or speak up.

“As least someone’s calling me something,” Harry rolled his eyes.

“She is really obsessed with school, it’s weird,” Liam agreed. “Why won’t she just join Kappa?”

“Won’t get off her fuckin’ high horse,” Harry muttered, drinking from a cup even though it wasn’t his turn. “She really knows how to get on my nerves. Trying to show her I can be a good boyfriend and this is what I get.”

“Can I come?” Louis asked. “Instead of Becks?”

“Sure, why not? You know what, why don’t you and Eleanor just take the tickets? Like I give a fuck. I might as well be here with the weirdo listening to stories about professors and papers,” Harry sighed dramatically.

Weirdo?  Becks’ jaw clenched.  She could tell from the unfocused look in Harry’s green eyes that he was drunk, but that was no excuse.  They had one little disagreement, and here he was telling anyone within earshot about how strange she was.

“So break up with her,” Liam shrugged.

Harry paused, and the pause broke her heart. “Nah, probably not.”

She had heard enough.  Turning on her heel, she pulled her glasses off and walked through the crowd as tears streaked down her cheeks.  Being a good student wasn’t a crime, at least, it shouldn’t be.  But maybe in the world of Harry Styles where solo cups were textbooks and coming up with lies to get out of things were essays, it was.

“Shit!” She heard Harry yell, and she quickened her pace.

She was not going to cry in front of him, and she wasn’t going to get into an argument in front of the entire party.

“Beck, Becks!” Harry panted, running after her. “Please wait up baby, please.”

“Oh, so now I’m your baby?” She couldn’t help it, turning around and putting her hands on her hips.

“N-no, don’t cry,” he said, reaching forward to dry her tears.

She smacked his hand away. “Don’t touch me.”

Harry sighed heavily. “I didn’t mean any of that, I never would have…”

“What? Never would have said it if you knew I was there? Would have waited until later when I was out of earshot?” She supplied some possible answers for him.

“I…” Harry wasn’t used to being put on the spot.

“I had no idea it was so difficult for you to be around me,” she said quietly, aware that everyone was listening. “Maybe you should stay away to help yourself feel better.”

“No, no,” he shook his head.

“Some boyfriend,” she said under her breath, walking away before he had the chance to come up with something.

She walked and walked, until she found herself back in her own room.  Pulling the dress off, she got into her pajamas as she continued to sob.  But her pajamas were an old t-shirt and boxers of Harry’s, so she ripped those off and got into bed naked.

She and Harry were different, and that was why they worked.  Or so she thought.  He was the crazy frat boy, and she was the good girl.  In some ways they made no sense, yet they meshed together perfectly.

Hearing him complain about her to anyone willing to listen hurt more than she could have imagined.  His words were ringing in her ears, no matter how hard she tried to block them out.  So she stuck her headphones in and fell asleep listening to breakup songs.



“Baby? Please open the door, I know you’re in there,” Harry groaned, leaning his forehead against her door.

Becks sat silently at her little kitchen table, working through a calculus problem.  He’d been out there for approximately thirteen minutes.  They were on day four of not speaking, mostly because of her.  He didn’t call or text her until two days after the incident, and she ignored him.  He kept texting and calling before switching to house calls.  But she hadn’t let him in, she couldn’t.

She felt like their entire two year relationship had been a lie.  They’d had their ups and downs, but nothing had ever been as hurtful as this.  She found herself wondering if maybe Harry was only with her as some sort of extended joke.

“Please?” His voice wobbled, and she held her face in her hands. “I miss you Becks, come on. Can you just talk to me?”

She cried silently, closing her textbook.  Getting work done was impossible when she was so completely miserable.

“Fine,” he mumbled. “I’ll try again tomorrow.”

Becks cried loudly once he was gone.  She didn’t know what to do.  Talking about it was terrifying, but she couldn’t ignore him forever.  He was still her boyfriend, even if he’d fucked up like this.

Kennedy had demanded her presence at dinner in the dining hall, so Becks set to icing her puffy, red eyes and picking out a outfit that had casual yes-I’m-fine undertones.  Sighing, she said a quick prayer that Harry would be eating at the frat house.

When Becks approached the usual Kappa table, she found Niall Horan on his knees at Kennedy’s feet.  Briefly forgetting her own problems, she sat down next to Della.

“Please, you can’t cancel,” Niall moaned. “It’s my favorite day of the year.”

“Oh, sorry Niall,” Kennedy mock pouted. “But Kappa will no longer be fraternizing with you boys. I heard the Alpha Phi girls are free, though. Probably because of that herpes outbreak, but you’ve got to take what you can get.”

“He’s sorry, he’s so sorry,” Niall insisted, grabbing her hands. “You can’t cancel the date party.”

“Too late,” Kennedy said, shaking him off.

“What’s going on?” Becks asked Della.

Della smiled at her. “We decided that we won’t be involved with them anymore. Kennedy told us what Harry was saying, that sucks.”

Becks’ cheeks turned red when she realized she was causing the chasm between the two groups.  On one hand she felt embarrassed, but on the other she hoped Harry was getting all of the blame for this.

“We’ll kick him out of the frat,” Niall said firmly. “Just say the word, he’s gone.”

“Well?” Kennedy raised an eyebrow, looking at Becks.

“No!” Becks shook her head rapidly. “You can’t kick him out, that’s insane. Just have the stupid date party.”

“What she said!” Niall nodded.

“She’s nice,” Kennedy frowned. “I’m not. Maybe you’ll remember this when you’re recruiting next year.”

Niall finally gave up, glaring at the table Harry was at as he left the dining hall. “Hey man, fuck you!”

Becks slouched lower in her seat, hoping that nobody knew what was going on and that it all revolved around her.

“You can have the party,” she said quietly, looking at Kennedy.

“No, we can’t,” Kennedy said firmly. “They’re clearly not up to par if that’s how they talk about people. It wasn’t just Harry, it was his friends. And Niall Horan kind of creeps me out, anyways.”

Priscilla, who frequently hooked up with Niall, rolled her eyes at that.

“So what are you doing if you’re not having the party?” Becks asked. “Don’t you have the place rented out and stuff?”

“She’s right,” Della frowned.

“Oh my God, I know!” Kennedy clapped her hands suddenly. “Makeover party!”

Becks winced, but the other girls all seemed thrilled at the prospect.  Everyone began calling her favorite salon to request their stylists for the night, giggling to one another as they were put on hold.

“And obviously you’re coming,” Kennedy said.

Becks pretended not to hear.

“Beckett, hello?” Kennedy said louder.

“Oh my God, stop,” Becks huffed. “Fine.”

“I hope the bar lets us have a makeover party,” Kennedy frowned. “Oh well, I’m sure it’ll be fine.”

Becks ate some of her salad as the girls planned.  She figured that even if she was losing her boyfriend, she still had some pretty amazing friends.



“Why do you even come to the library?” Priscilla asked. “You get straight A’s even if you don’t study.”

“Just wanted a change of scenery,” Becks mumbled.

She was seated at the Kappa table in the library, which was currently full of sorority sisters cramming for their midterms.  Not that Becks needed to fit any more studying in, but staying in her own room was a hazard.  Harry was constantly trying to talk to her, so she needed some peace and quiet.  Unfortunately, that meant sitting in the library.

“Oh my God,” Della whispered. “Look.”

Becks didn’t bother looking up.  She didn’t want to gossip or people watch.  She just wanted to get a head start on her reading, go to bed, and hopefully not cry tonight.  It had now been six days since she spoke to Harry.  She thought that it would get easier, but it didn’t.  It was still just as heartbreaking as it had been in that moment.

“Look!” Kennedy pinched her thigh, making her jump.

“What?” Becks hissed.

Kennedy nodded at the entrance.  The girls always sat on the third floor of the library, because everyone knew that was the cool area.  It was the best place for people watching, and the Starbucks was on this floor.

Harry was walking in, carrying a bouquet of flowers and wearing a flannel.  In other words, dressed up more so than usual.  Running a hand through his hair, his eyes locked with hers.

“Good evening, ladies,” he said, approaching the table.

“Walk away,” Kennedy said, leaning back in her seat and crossing her arms over her chest.

“Don’t think so,” he said, giving her an annoying little smile as he stepped up onto the table. “Uh, excuse me? Can I have everyone’s attention?”

Had anyone else stepped on a table in the middle of the library and demanded everyone’s consideration, they would have been laughed out of the building.  But it was Harry, so people stopped what they were doing and listened.

“So last week, I really hurt my girlfriend’s feelings at a party. I was trying to do something nice, but I didn’t really ask her about her opinion on the matter and I got really frustrated and screamed at her,” Harry sighed, not even blushing under all of the eyes on him.

Becks stared up at him with wide eyes, unable to believe this was happening.

“And after that I got really drunk, and I was telling anyone who would listen all sorts of lies to make myself feel better about fucking up. I thought she’d left, but she was there and she heard. Hi, Beck, how’s it going?” He smiled down at her, seeming to forget where he was for a moment.

“Hi,” she whispered, hands shaking as she held her book.

“Now you won’t talk to me. You ignore me when I knock at your door, and all of your friends are ignoring me too. And I… I can’t lose you. I don’t want to go back to life without you,” he shook his head.

Several girls let out awww’s at that.

“I love you more than anything. I love you as much as you love school. Which is fine, there’s nothing wrong with loving school. Someone’s got to, I suppose,” he said, giving her a tiny smile. “And I shouldn’t make fun of you, or anyone else, to make myself feel better. I should never have jeopardized our relationship. I know that now.”

Her eyes were tearing now, because it was like he’d somehow read her mind and figured out everything she wanted to hear in an apology.

“Please just talk to me,” he begged, getting down on his knees so he was nearly at her level. “I miss you so much, and I love you.”

“Harry,” she sniffled, wiping a tear away.

“Hmm?” He leaned in closer, an anxious look on his face.

“I love you too, can you get down?” She asked, smiling at him.

Harry sat down on her notebooks.  He handed her the bouquet he’d been holding, smiling shyly.

“I miss you so much,” he mumbled, finally noticing how everyone was watching with rapt attention.

“I miss you too,” she nodded, hugging the flowers to her chest.

Becks stood up and kissed him, making everyone begin to applaud wildly.  Her cheeks burned as she buried her face against his neck.  Harry placed his hands on the small of her back, pressing kisses to the top of her head.

“I am so sorry,” he sighed. “More than I can say. I love you and your books and flashcards and all of it.”

“I love you too,” she murmured, picking her head up as the clapping subsided.

“You wanna sleep over tonight?” He asked, pulling her closer.

“Let’s sleep at mine,” she suggested, indicating the flowers. “I should put these in water.”

“Right,” he agreed, picking up her things and shouldering her backpack. “Oh, and Kennedy?”

“Yeah?” Kennedy tried to stop smiling at the cuteness.

“Please still have the formal, I think Niall’s experiencing clinical depression over it,” he grinned.

“I’ll see what I can do,” she nodded.

“You and I aren’t going,” Harry told Becks as they walked out of the library.

“Why?” She frowned.

“Because we won’t be here that weekend,” he shook his head. “Our flight leaves after your Friday lab, and we get back Sunday around eleven at night. Don’t worry about being tired for your Monday morning lit class, I talked to your professor and she was going to cancel that class anyways.”

“Really?” She smiled widely.

“You shouldn’t miss stuff if you don’t want to,” he shrugged, holding her hand tightly. “And I checked with all of your other professors, you haven’t got any tests or papers due the week we’re back, so you shouldn’t have too much homework.”

She stopped and kissed him. “I love you.”

“I love you like Niall loves Kappa,” he grinned.

“Shut up,” she rolled her eyes.

“In all seriousness,” Harry cleared his throat. “I fucked up and I want to make it up to you. Whatever it takes.”

“You don’t have to make it up to me,” she shook her head, unlocking her door.

“I can try,” he grinned, putting the flowers down. “Now c’mere, it’s been a lonely six days.”

“Can you write something where fratboy harry is dating the weird girl who is friends w a bunch of sorority girls but isn’t in one. And then one day she over hears harry and his friends talking ab how weird she is and she gets offended (obv) and he feels really bad after because she hasn’t talked to him and all of her sorority friends hate him for what he said please and thank you baby goose!!!🤪”
